abstract.t: Cleartext JSON Web Signature (JWS) represents signed data as cleartext JSON objects. The signature is included in the JSON object to be signed. Cleartext JWS builds on JWS , JWA and JWK , including for representations of header parameters, algorithms, and cryptographic keys. Serialization of the JSON object to be signed uses the predictable serialization defined in ECMAScript version 6. Cleartext JWS reuses data structures and semantics from JWS whenever practical and reasonable. Cryptographic algorithms and identifiers used by this specification are defined in the JSON Web Algorithms specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Cleartext JSON Web Signature (JWS) represents signed data as cleartext JSON objects. The signature is included in the JSON object to be signed. By enveloping the signature in the JSON object to be signed, it is easy to inspect data in transit and when archived, integrity can be guaranteed. Cryptographic algorithms and identifiers used by this specification are defined in the JSON Web Algorithms (JWA) specification.

Cleartext JWS reuses constructs from JWS, JWA, and JWK whenever practical and reasonable. Header parameters from JWS, algorithms from JWA, and the key representation JWK are used. There are two essential differences from JWS. First, Cleartext JWS signatures are included in the signed data. Second, Cleartext JWS depends on predictable JSON Serialization rather than base64url encoding the data to be signed. The table below shows the primary characteristics of the JWS variants:

texttable.c: Non-intrusive signature object for inclusion in arbitrary JSON and JavaScript objects

section.t: In the following example, there are a few things to note. The signature is included in the data (aka enveloped signature). The members in the __cleartext_signature object are the JWS header parameters. The signature member contains the base64url encoded signature bytes.
Note that the signature value was cut in two to cope with RFC line length constraints.
The key specified in can be used for verifying the example signature.
Note: Recreating the example signature using the example private key would normally result in a different signature value since ECDSA relies on random data for signature generation.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: The Signature Object
section.t: When signing JSON data with Cleartext JWS a JSON object with the JWS Header Parameters are created and placed within the JSON data to be signed. In addition to the already defined JWS Header Parameters Cleartext JWS defines two new Header Parameters signature for the base64url encoded signature value and signers to support multiple signers within the same signature object.
The identifier for the Cleartext Signature Object in the JSON data to be signed MUST be __cleartext_signature, unless the application specifies that a different identifier is to be used.

section.title: Signature Scope
section.t: The scope of a signature, what is actually signed, comprises all properties including possible child objects of the JSON object holding the signature property except for the signature member.

section.title: The "signature" Header Parameter
section.t: The signature Header Parameter contains the base64url-encoded JWS Signature as a string.

section.title: The "signers" Header Parameter
section.t: The optional signers Header Parameter contains an array of signatures. See .

section.title: Message Signature or MAC Computation
section.t: To create a Cleartext JWS, the following steps are performed. The order of the steps is not significant in cases where there are no dependencies between the inputs and outputs of the steps.

list.t: Create the JSON object to be signed.
Create the __cleartext_signature object with the header parameters to be used and add it as a top-level member to the object to be signed with the key __cleartext_signature.
Serialize the object to be signed using the Serialization and normalization rules defined in .

Compute the JWS Signature in the manner defined for the particular algorithm being used over the serialized object to be signed. The alg (algorithm) Header Parameter MUST be present in the __cleartext_signature member, with the algorithm value accurately representing the algorithm used to construct the JWS Signature.
Add the signature member to the signature object with the encoded Cleartext JWS signature and assign it the string value BASE64URL(JWS Signature).

section.title: Message Signature or MAC Validation
section.t: When validating a Cleartext JWS, the following steps are performed. The order of the steps is not significant in cases where there are no dependencies between the inputs and outputs of the steps. If any of the listed steps fails, then the input MUST be rejected.

When there are multiple Cleartext JWS Signature values, it is an application decision which of the Cleartext JWS Signature values must successfully validate for the Cleartext JWS to be accepted. In some cases, all must successfully validate, or the Cleartext JWS will be considered invalid. In other cases, only a specific Cleartext JWS Signature value needs to be successfully validated. However, in all cases, at least one Cleartext JWS Signature value MUST successfully validate, or the Cleartext JWS MUST be considered invalid.

list.t: Parse JSON data including enveloped signature.

Verify that the implementation understands and can process all fields that it is required to support, whether required by this specification, by the algorithm being used, or by the crit Header Parameter value, and that the values of those parameters are also understood and supported.
Save and remove the signature member from the signature object and base64url-decode the encoded representation of the Cleartext JWS Signature.
Serialize and normalize the signed object including the signature object, by following the rules in .

Validate the Cleartext JWS Signature against the Cleartext JWS Signing Input, i.e., the Serialized and Normalized data, in the manner defined for the algorithm being used, which MUST be accurately represented by the value of the alg (algorithm) Header Parameter value, which MUST be present. Record whether the validation succeeded or not.
Return a result indicating whether or not the Cleartext JWS was successfully validated.
For later validation of the signed object, put back the signature member back into the JSON data structure.

section.title: Serialization and Normalization
section.t: When having header parameters in cleartext serialization of them needs to be consistent across platforms. JSON by itself does not produce predictable serialization of data. However, ES6 defines how to produce JSON that is predictable. By following the ES6 serialization directives, one gets predictable results, i.e., the JSON serializer MUST follow the directives set out by ES6 when serializing data. The rules defined below take the essence from the ES6 specification and list what that means in practical terms.

Rules for serialization:
The original property serialization order MUST be preserved as described by ECMAScript section 9.1.12.
JSON data of the type Number, MUST be processed according to ECMAScript section 7.1.12.1.
Property names MUST be unique.
Whitespace must be removed which in practical terms means removal of all characters outside of quoted strings having a value of x09, x0a, x0d or x20.
JSON '\/' escape sequences within quoted strings must be treated as "degenerate" equivalents to '/' by rewriting them.
Unicode escape sequences (\uhhhh) within quoted strings must be adjusted as follows: If the Unicode value falls within the traditional ASCII control character range (0x00-0x1f and 0x7f), it must be rewritten in lowercase hexadecimal notation unless it is one of the predefined JSON escapes (\" \\ \b \f \n \r \t) because the latter have precedence. If the Unicode value is outside of the ASCII control character range, it must be replaced by the corresponding Unicode character. See ECMAScript section 24.3.2.2.
If these rules are applied to the example signature, it should result in the following string (with line wraps between elements for display purposes only):
Note: \u20ac denotes the Euro symbol which is a single character, currently not displayable "as is" in RFCs.
The final step is converting the textual output into an UTF-8 formatted array. Applied to the sample this should yield the following bytes here shown in decimal notation:

section.title: ES6+ Interoperability
section.t: For JavaScript optimization reasons, ES6+'s JSON.parse() internally rearranges the order of properties with names expressed as integers, making a parsed JSON string like '{"2":"First", "A":"Second","1":"Third"}' actually serialize as '{"1":"Third","2":"First","A":"Second"}'. Due to this fact, signature creators MUST "emulate" this scheme since this behavior is not intended to be an additional requirement to support by JSON tools in general in order to use this specification. The easiest way accomplishing this is to programmatically make sure that possible numeric property names always are created first and added in ascending order.

section.title: Multiple Signatures
section.t: Multiple signatures enable different keys to independently of each other add a signature to a JSON object.

The normalization procedure is essentially the same as for single signatures but must also take the following in account as well:
There MUST be an additional Cleartext JWS Header parameter signers, holding an array of signature constructs.
Each signature requires its own normalization process. During this process, the other signature constructs MUST (temporarily) be removed.
The normalized data MUST include the array brackets ([]) but MUST NOT include the comma separating the signature constructs.
A signature construct is equivalent to an ordinary Cleartext JWS object, but MAY exclude the alg Header parameter which then MUST be declared in the Cleartext JWS object itself. Using the latter arrangement, all enclosed signature constructs MUST use the same algorithm as well as not specifying the alg Header parameter. See for an example.
If a crit Header parameter is specified in the Cleartext JWS object itself, this declaration MUST be applied to all signature constructs. Such a declaration MUST NOT be combined with crit Header parameters in the enclosed signature constructs. See for an example.
The following example shows a multiply signed object:
The ECDSA signature can be validated using the key specified in , while the RSA signature can be validated using the key specified in .

section.title: JSON Header Parameters Registry
section.t: This section registers the signature and signers header parameter in the "JSON Web Signature and Encryption Header Parameters" registry in the manner described in .

list.t: Header Parameter Name: signature
Header Parameter Description: The base64url-encoded signature value.
Header Parameter Usage Location(s): CT-JWS
Change Controller: IESG
Specification Document(s):
Header Parameter Name: signers
Header Parameter Description: List of signers, each with a set of headers and a signature.
Header Parameter Usage Location(s): CT-JWS
Change Controller: IESG
Specification Document(s):

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This specification does (to the authors' knowledge), not introduce additional vulnerabilities over what is specified for JWS .

section.title: Acknowledgements
section.t: This document builds on the work done in the JOSE WG so a big thanks goes out to all involved in that work. It is specifically inspired by JWS, so a special thanks to the authors of that document, Michael B. Jones, John Bradley, and Nat Sakimura.
Building on ES6 number normalization was originally proposed by James Manger. This ultimately led to the adoption of the entire ES6 JSON processing model.

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: This section contains a set of test vectors sharing a common characteristic, long lines are sliced in order to cope with RFC line length constraints.
